question: $P \lor Q$, if $P$ is false and $Q$ is false, what is the result?
information: The logical OR ($\lor$) returns true if at least one of the operands is true. Here, both $P$ and $Q$ are false, so the whole proposition is false.

question: $P \rightarrow Q$, if $P$ is true and $Q$ is true, what is the result?
information: The logical implication ($\rightarrow$) is true unless a true hypothesis leads to a false conclusion. Here, since $P$ is true and $Q$ is also true, the whole proposition is true.

question: $\lnot P$, if $P$ is false, what is the result?
information: The logical NOT ($\lnot$) negates the value of $P$. Since $P$ is false, $\lnot P$ is true.

question: $P \land Q$, if $P$ is true and $Q$ is false, what is the result?
information: The logical AND ($\land$) is true only if both $P$ and $Q$ are true. Here, since $Q$ is false, the whole proposition is false.

question: $\lnot (P \lor Q)$, if $P$ is false and $Q$ is true, what is the result?
information: The proposition $\lnot (P \lor Q)$ is true only if both $P$ and $Q$ are false. Here, since $Q$ is true, the whole proposition is false.

question: $\lnot ((P \land Q) \rightarrow (\lnot P \lor \lnot Q))$, if $P$ is true and $Q$ is false, what is the result?
information: since $P$ is true and $Q$ is false, the result of $(P \land Q)$ is false. $(\lnot P \lor \lnot Q)$ is true, the implication $(P \land Q) \rightarrow (\lnot P \lor \lnot Q)$ is true. Ultimately, taking the negation of this implication results in $\lnot ((P \land Q) \rightarrow (\lnot P \lor \lnot Q))$ being false.

question: $(P \lor \lnot Q) \land (\lnot P \rightarrow Q)$, if $P$ is false and $Q$ is false, what is the result?
information: Since $P$ is false and $Q$ is false, the expression $P \lor \lnot Q$ becomes $\text{false} \lor \text{true}$, which is true. The expression $\lnot P \rightarrow Q$ becomes $\text{true} \rightarrow \text{false}$, which is false. Therefore, the overall expression $(P \lor \lnot Q) \land ( \lnot P \rightarrow Q)$ is $\text{true} \land \text{false}$, which is false.

question: $\lnot (P \leftrightarrow (Q \land (P \lor \lnot Q)))$, if $P$ is true and $Q$ is true, what is the result?
information: Given $P$ is true and $Q$ is true, $P \lor \lnot Q$ is true. Thus, $Q \land (P \lor \lnot Q)$ is also true, making the biconditional $P \leftrightarrow (Q \land (P \lor \lnot Q))$ true. Taking the negation of this true biconditional, $\lnot (P \leftrightarrow (Q \land (P \lor \lnot Q)))$, results in false.

question: $((P \rightarrow \lnot Q) \land (\lnot P \lor Q))$, if $P$ is false and $Q$ is true, what is the result?
information: Given $P$ is false and $Q$ is true, the implication $P \rightarrow \lnot Q$ is true as the antecedent is false. Similarly, the disjunction $\lnot P \lor Q$ is also true, since the disjunct $\lnot P$ is true. Consequently, the conjunction $((P \rightarrow \lnot Q) \land (\lnot P \lor Q))$ of these true propositions is true.

question: $\lnot (P \land (Q \lor (\lnot P \rightarrow Q)))$, if $P$ is true and $Q$ is false, what is the result?
information: Given $P$ is true and $Q$ is false, the implication $\lnot P \rightarrow Q$ evaluates to true, as the antecedent is false. Then, the disjunction $Q \lor (\lnot P \rightarrow Q)$ becomes true as one of the disjuncts is true. Finally, the conjunction $P \land (Q \lor (\lnot P \rightarrow Q))$ is true, thus the negation $\lnot (P \land (Q \lor (\lnot P \rightarrow Q)))$ is false.
